column12: Internal acoustic meatus, facial canal, geniculate ganglion. Divides into 5 branches usually within parotid gland. Sensation from part of tympanic membrane, external accoustic meatus and skin behind pinna. Proprioception from facial muscles. Taste from anterior two-thirds of tongue. Parasympathic to lacrimal gland and mucous membrane of nasal and oral cavities (via pterygopalatine ganglion) and submandibular and sublingual salivary glands (via submandibular ganglion). Stylomastoid foramen
column13: Exits skull at stylomastoid foramen, initially deep to the posterior margin of the external acoustic meatus, nerve trunk lies approx 1cm inferomedial to the tip of the tragal pointer and runs anterior to the mastoid apex and C1 transverse process (Gray's p 412). Detailed description of its pathway in Gray's Anatomy p 638.
column14: 2 roots travel in petrous part of temporal bone. Leave internal acoustic meatus and enter facial canal. Roots fuse there to form facial nerve. Nerve forms geniculate ganglion. Gives rise to greater petrosal nerve (parasympathetic fibres to mucous glands and lacrimal gland), nerve to stapedius (motor fibres to stapedius muscle), chorda tympani (sensory fibres to anterior 2/3 of tongue and parasympathetic fibres to submandibular and sublingual glands). Nerve then exits facial canal and cranium through stylomastoid foramen. Then gives off posterior auricular nerve (motor to muscles around ear and then digastric and stylohyoid muscles, cutaneous sensation from skin over mastoid process and parts of auricle). Netter's Atlas plate 54 shows the facial nerve dividing into 2 divisions within the parotid gland: A temporofacial division, and a cervicofacial division. Facial nerve then divides into 5 branches within parotid gland: Temporal, zygomatic, buccal (from temporofacial division), and buccal, marginal mandibular and cervical branches (muscles of facial expression) (from cervicofacial division). There are many communicating branches from these motor branches to nerves that also serve non-motor functions.

Jugular foramen, carotid sheath
General sensation from pharynx, larynx, trachea, oesophagus, part of auricle and external auditory meatus. Sensory from thoracic and abdominal viscera, sensory from aortic arch and aortic bodies. Parasympathetic to glands and smooth muscle in the pharynx, larynx, thoracic and abdominal viscera. column13: Accompanied by the accessory nerve as it exits the jugular foramen, they share an arachnoid and dural sheath. Both nerves lie anterior to a fibrous septum that separates them from the glossopharyngeal nerve. Vagus descends vertically in the neck in the carotid sheath, between the internal jugular vein and the internal carotid artery, to the upper border of the thyroid cartilage, then passes between the vein and the common carotid artery to the root of the neck. R Vagus then descends posterior to the internal jugular vein to cross the first part of the subclavian artery and enter the thorax. Left Vagus enters the thorax between the left common carotid and subclavian arteries and behind the left brachiocephalic vein. R Vagus descends posterior to the internal jugular vein to cross the first part of the subclavian artery and enter the thorax.
column14:
Cell bodies of the sensory neurons are in the superior and inferior ganglia in the jugular foramen and fossa in the inferior part of the temporal bone at the base of the skull. The motor neurons are in the medulla (lower part of the brainstem) in the nucleus ambiguus and the dorsal motor nucleus of the vagus.
Superior (jugular) ganglion of vagus nerve: Small round superior enlargement on vagus nerve just after emerging from the jugular foramen. Connected to the inferior glossopharyngeal ganglion and the sympathetic trunk, the latter by a filament from the superior cervical ganglion. Sensory, contains somatic, special visceral and general visceral afferent neurones. Chiefly somatic, most of its neurones enter the auricular nerve.
Inferior (nodose) ganglion of vagus nerve: Larger inferior cylindrical enlargement on vagus nerve just after emerging from the jugular foramen. Connected with the hypoglossal nerve, the loop between the first and second cervical spinal nerves, and with the superior cervical sympathetic ganglion. Inferior ganglion neurones receive visceral sensation from heart, lungs, larynx and the alimentary tract from the pharynx to the transverse colon.

column13:
Branches off Superior Laryngeal Nerve 35.2 +/- 0.2mm from bifurcation of carotid artery, traverses from lateral to medial at area between thyroid cartilage and hyoid bone, distance from midline: at C2-3 intervertebral disc level = 24.2 +/- 3.3mm, at C3-4 = 20.2 +/- 3.6mm, at C4-5 = 15.9 +/- 4.3mm. Passes immediatety inferior to greater horn of hyoid bone, approaches thyrohyoid membrane (TM) accompanied by superior laryngeal artery, both pierce external surface of TM. Pierces TM at C4-5 level. 
Branches into Superior Branch of (ibSLN) to innervate mucosa of epiglottis and small part of anterior wall of the vallecula, Middle (sensory) Branch which innervates aryepiglottic folds, and Inferior Branch which sends a few twigs to the interarytenoid muscles (also called arytenoid muscle). Branching occurs more frequently distal but sometimes proximal to TM. Ultimately pierces the inferior pharyngeal constrictor to unite with an ascending branch from the recurrent laryngeal nerve (Gray's p 467). As it ascends neck, it supplies branches to the mucosa and tunica muscularis of the oesophagus and trachea and to the inferior constrictor.

Kiray et al say the point at which the nerve branches is at C1 level 20.83% of their cases, C2 level 58.34% and C2-3 disc space 20.83%.

column13: On the R it arises from vagus anterior to the first part of the subclavian artery, curves backwards below and then behind it to ascend obliquely to the side of the trachea behind the common carotid artery. Near the lower pole of the lateral lobe of the thyroid gland it is closely related to the inferior thyroid artery and crosses either in front of, behind or between its branches. On the L the recurrent laryngeal nerve arises from the vagus on the left of the aortic arch, curves below it immediately behind the attachment of the ligamentum arteriosum to the concavity of the aortic arch and ascends to the side of the trachea. As it curves around the subclavian artery, it gives cardiac filaments to the deep cardiac plexus. On both sides it ascends in or near a groove between the trachea and oesophagus. It is closely related to the medial surface of the thyroid gland before it passes under the lower border of the inferior constrictor, enters the larynx behind the articulation of the inferior thyroid cornu with the cricoid cartilage. It communicates with the internal laryngeal nerve, supplying sensory filaments to the laryngeal muscle below the vocal folds. Carries afferent fibres from laryngeal stretch receptors.

column12:
These are multiple branches which leave as laryngopharyngeal branches and cardiac branches as listed below.
Laryngopharyngeal branches to carotid body and pharyngeal plexus. Cardiac branch on R joins deep part of cardiac plexus behind aortic arch and has connections to external laryngeal nerve, vagal cardiac branches, recurrent laryngeal nerve and thyroid branches of middle cervical ganglion. Cardiac branch on L joins superficial (ventral) part of cardiac plexus (and sometimes it descends on the right of the aorta to reach the deep part of the plexus). Communicates with cardiac branches of middle and inferior cervical sympathetic ganglia and sometimes inferior cervical cardiac branches of L vagus to form plexus on ascending aorta.
column13: Laryngopharyngeal branches supply carotid body and pass to the side of the pharynx, joining glossopharyngeal and vagal rami to form the pharyngeal plexus. Cardiac branch arises from the lower part of the superior cervical ganglion and occasionally receives a twig from the trunk between the superior and middle cervical ganglia. Descends behind the common carotid artery, in front of longus colli and crosses anterior to the inferior thyroid artery and recurrent laryngeal nerve. The courses then differ on the two sides of the body. The right cardiac branch usually passes behind, but sometimes in front of, the subclavian artery and runs posterolateral to the brachiocephalic trunk to join the deep (dorsal) part of the cardiac plexus behind the aortic arch (More detail in Gray's Anatomy p 468). The left cardiac branch, in the thorax, is anterior to the left common carotid artery and crosses in front of the laft side of the aortic arch to reach the superficial (ventral) part of the cardiac plexus. Sometimes it descends on the right of the aora to end in the deep part of the cardiac plexus. (More detail in Gray's Anatomy p 468).

column12: L and R phrenic each have a different course.
column13:
From anterior rami of C3, C4 and C5 spinal nerves, communicating fibres from cervical plexus and cervical sympathetic ganglia. Phrenic nerve forms at upper part of lateral border of scalenus anterior, descends nearly vertically across its anterior surface behind the prevertebral fascia. Descends posterior to sternocleidomastoid, inferior belly of omohyoid (near its intermediate tendon), the internal jugular vein, transverse cervical and suprascapular arteries (and the thoracic duct for the left phrenic). At the root of the neck it runs anterior to the second part of the subclavian artery, separated from it by scelanus anterior, and posterior to the subclavian vein. Crosses medially in front of the internal thoracic artery to enter the thorax.
Within the thorax, the phrenic nerve descends anterior to the pulmonary hilum between the fibrous pericardium and mediastinal pleura.
It sends sensory branches to the mediastinal pleura, fibrous pericardium and parietal serous pericardium. Motor fibres to diaphragm, sensory fibres from central part of diaphragm, surrounding pleura, peritoneum, mediastinal pleura and pericardium.
column14:
In the neck the phrenic nerves receive variable filaments from the cervical sympathetic ganglia or their branches and may also connect with internal thoracic sympathetic plexuses.
Fine branches to parietal pleura above diaphragm and parietal peritoneum below diaphragm.

column12:
R phrenic: Shorter and more vertical than left phrenic. Separated at the root of the neck from the second part of the right subclavian artery by scalenus anterior. Descends lateral to right brachiocephalic vein, superior vena cava, fibrous pericardium covering the right surface of the right atrium and inferior vena cava. Divides just superior to or at the level of the diaphragm. Passes through the central tendon of the diaphragm, either by the caval hiatus or just lateral to it. Fine branches to parietal pleura and parietal peritoneum. Usually branches into 3 as it passes through the diaphragm. Anterior (sternal) branch passes anteromedially towards sternum and connects with similar branch from left phrenic. Anterolateral branch runs to lateral leaf of central tendon, and a short posterior branch which divides into a poaterolateral ramus that courses posterior to the lateral leaf and a posterior ramus that supplies the crural fibres.(Gray's p 973)
Passes anteriorly over the lateral part of the R subclavian artery, enters thorax via superior thoracic aperture, descends anteriorly along R lung root, travels along pericardium of R atrium of heart, pierces diaphragm at inferior vena cava opening, innervates inferior surface of diaphragm.

L phrenic: At the root of the neck, the left phrenic commonly leaves the medial edge of scalenus anterior and passes anterior to the first part of the left subclavian artery and posterior to the thoracic duct. (May also copy right phrenic and cross anterior to the second part of the left subclavian artery, from which it is separated by scalenus anterior, at the level of the thoracic inlet). Left phrenic then crosses anterior to the left internal thoracic artery and descends across the medial aspect of the apex of the left lung and its pleura to the first part of the subclavian artery, which it crosses obliquely to reach a groove between the left common carotid and subclavian arteries. It passes anteromedially, superficial to the left vagus nerve just superior to the aortic arch and posterior to the left brachiocephalic vein, then descends superficial to the aortic arch and the left superior intercostal vein, anterior to the left pulmonary hilum, to lie between the fibrous pericardium covering the surface of the left ventricle and the mediastinal pleura. 
Left phrenic passes through the muscular part of the diaphragm anterior to the central tendon, just lateral to the left cardiac surface and more anterior than the right phrenic nerve. Fine branches to parietal pleura and parietal peritoneum.
Usually branches into 3 as it passes through the diaphragm. Anterior (sternal) branch passes anteromedially towards sternum and connects with similar branch from right phrenic. Anterolateral branch runs to lateral leaf of central tendon, and a short posterior branch which divides into a poaterolateral ramus that courses posterior to the lateral leaf and a posterior ramus that supplies the crural fibres.

column8: Formed from Ventral rami of C5-8 and T1. Starts in posterior triangle of neck in angle between clavicle and lower posterior border of sternocleidomastoid.
column12: Roots and trunks of brachial plexus in line passing between middle of posterior border of sternocleidomastoid and middle of clavicle, interscalene groove, posterior to scalenus anterior, divisions lie behind the clavicle near the lateral border of the first rib, the cords enter the axilla above the first part of the subclavian artery, embrace its second part and give off branches around the third part.
column13:
5 roots contribute to form plexus from C5-8 and T1 anterior rami. Upper 2 roots combine to form upper trunk, ventral root forms middle trunk, lower 2 roots form lower trunk. The 5 roots lie behind scalenus anterior muscle and emerge from between it and scalenus medius to form trunks. Trunks cross lower part of posterior triangle of neck. Each of the trunks divides into an anterior and posterior division behind the clavicle. Here at the outer border of the first rib, the upper 2 anterior divisions unite to form the lateral cord, the anterior division of the lower trunk runs on as the medial cord, and all three posterior divisions unite to form the posterior cord. The 3 cords enter the axilla above the first part of the axillary artery within the axillary sheath and their branches emerge around the third part of the artery. 
Rami communicans bring sympathetic fibres to join each root of the brachial plexus

column12: Lateral cutaneous branches branch off intercostal nerves about midway between vertebrae and sternum. They pierce the external intercostal muscles and serratus anterior and divide into anterior and posterior branches. Anterior branches run forward and supply front of chest and skin. Posterior branches run backwards and supply skin over scapula and latissimus dorsi. Lateral cutaneous branch of T2 doesn't divide into anterior and posterior branches but instead forms the intercostobrachial nerve.

column13:
Tibial part of sciatic nerve is formed from the union of branches from all 5 anterior divisions (L4, 5, S1, 2, 3). Common fibular part of sciatic nerve is formed by union of branches from posterior divisions of L4, 5, S1, 2. It usually but not always joins the tibial part to form a combined nerve. 
Sciatic nerve is formed at the lower margin of piriformis by the union of the tibial and common fibular parts and emerges into the buttock lying on the ischium. Midway between the greater trochanter and ischial tuberosity, it passes vertically downwards into the hamstring compartment. It lies on obturator internus and gemelli, quadratus femoris and then on adductor magnus. It is overlaid by the long head of biceps.
Sciatic nerve runs vertically through the hamstring compartment, deep to the long head of biceps, between it and the underlying adductor magnus. At the apex of the popliteal fossa it divides into its tibial and common fibular components.

column13: Tibial nerve runs vertically down along middle of popliteal fossa and passes deeply between the heads of gastrocnemius. Popliteal artery is deep and medial to tibial nerve. Tibial nerve passes with popliteal vessels anterior and beneath the fibrous arch in the origin of soleus. Enters calf. Runs straight down midline of calf deep to soleus, lying on the fibular aponeurosis of flexor digitorum longus. Posterior tibial artery is at first lateral to it but passes deep to it at the origin of its peroneal branch and continues downwards on its medial side. Gives motor branches to plantaris, both heads of gastrocnemius, soleus and popliteus. The last branch hooks around the lower border of popliteus to enter its deep (tibial) surface. The nerve ends under the middle of the flexor retinaculum by dividing into medial and lateral plantar nerves.

column12: Sural nerve is a cutaneous branch of tibial nerve. It runs vertically down between the two heads of gastrocnemius and pierces the deep fascia halfway down the calf. Passing down in the subcutaneous fat it joins the peroneal communicating nerve below the bellies of gastrocnemius where it is close to and usually lateral to the small saphenous vein. Descends lateral to calcaneal tendon. With the saphenous vein it runs behind the lateral malleolus. Supplies posterior and lateral skin of distal third of leg. Connects with posterior femoral cutaneous nerve in the leg and with the superficial fibular nerve on the dorsum of the foot.
column13: Originates from the sural nerve complex which is formed from a highly variable set of contributing nerves. Most commonly from the sural nerve/medial sural cutaneous nerve (from the tibial nerve) and the sural communicating branch (from the common fibular nerve), but also at times from an anastomosis of the lateral sural cutaneous nerve (from the common fibular nerve) and the sural/medial sural cutaneous nerve (from the tibial nerve). Becomes the lateral dorsal cutaneous nerve towards its terminating point in the fourth and fifth digits.
column14: The sural nerve (sometimes called the medial sural cutaneous nerve) is joined at a variable level by the sural communicating branch of the common fibular nerve (sometimes called the lateral sural cutaneous nerve)
